UserProfile.title: UserProfile
UserProfile.description: Represents a user's profile within the TypeRush application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the UserProfile entity.

highestWPM.description: The user's highest recorded typing speed (words per minute).

gamesPlayed.description: The total number of games the user has played.

LeaderboardEntry.title: LeaderboardEntry
LeaderboardEntry.description: Represents a single entry on the leaderboard.

id.description: Unique identifier for the LeaderboardEntry entity.

username.description: The username associated with this leaderboard entry.

score.description: The score achieved by the user.

timestamp.description: The timestamp indicating when the score was achieved.

definition.description: Stores user profile data. Path-based ownership ensures only the authenticated user can access their profile. Includes 'id', 'username', 'email', 'highestWPM', and 'gamesPlayed'.

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier of the user, corresponding to their Firebase Authentication UID.

definition.description: Stores leaderboard entries. Includes denormalized 'username' from UserProfile for authorization independence. Includes 'userId', 'username', 'score', and 'timestamp'.

params.name: leaderboardEntryId
params.description: The unique identifier for the leaderboard entry.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore data structure is designed to support user authentication (email/password, guest), profile storage, leaderboard functionality, and game statistics tracking in the TypeRush application. The structure prioritizes authorization independence and clear security rules. User profiles are stored in a private collection `/users/{userId}`, ensuring only the authenticated user can access their own profile. Leaderboard entries are stored in a global collection `/leaderboard`, allowing efficient querying and display of top scores. The `username` is denormalized into the `LeaderboardEntry` documents to avoid needing to perform a `get()` operation from the `users` collection in security rules to ensure that the user still has that username. This is critical for atomic updates. All reads on the `leaderboard` collection can be granted if the `username` matches the user and the `userId` is valid.
